The Convention was presented to Parliament last year (1919, Cd. 260). The Bill contains the necessary power to give effect to the Convention, and it is proposed to apply the principles of the Convention not only as respects the cases to which it specifically relates, that is to say, international flying, but also to internal flying in the British Islands. The Bill repeals the existing statutes governing air navigation, which will in future be regulated entirely by the principles adopted in the Convention and applied by this Bill.Part II. of the Bill effects some specific amendments in the law, which are partly incidental to carrying the Convention into effect. It contains special provisions for the control of aviation in the case of national emergency, and defines certain principles of liability in relation to damage caused by aircraft to property on land or water.I circuit.te this rail for the considerationof the G&M&fct'Air ministry.26th April,32-8a For the Cabinet *AIR NAVIGATION BILL, Notes on Clauses,The general scope of the Bill is described to the Explanatory Memorandum prefixed to it. The following notes are therefore confined to such clauses as appear to merit special notice.Clause 1.The Convention relates mainly to Inter-state flying, and this clause enables its provisions to be carried out as regards such flying.Clause 2,It is desirable to assimilate the main rules for home flying to those for inter-state flying and the clause enables this to be done.Clause 3.The repeal by this Bill of the existing Air Navigation Acts makes it necessary to make provision for continuing the powers given by those Acts, particularly as the Convention does not deal with points such as licensing of aerodromes and general safety regulations, Subsection l(k), dealing with the control of lights near aerial lighthouses, is rendered necessary by the probable develop-ment of night flying ,while the existing powers of general lighthouse authorities (who control coastal lights) are expressly preserved by Clause 17 (2)*Clause 7?This clause is considered necessary in order to suppress all civilian flying throughout the whole country in case of emergency ** the Convention only allows in peace specified prohibited areas duly notified - and also in order to commandeer aerodromes with their plants Originally this clause required the prior communication of the occasion to Parliament, but in view of the possible sudden outbreak of an emergency, including in that term one produced by a serious industrial crisis, the reference has been deleted.Clause 8pAt present municipalities have no power to establish or maintain aerodromes. PREFATORY NOTE.The differences between the final Convention and that printed in Cmd Paper No. 260 are due to the revision of the Instrument by the general Drafting Committee of the Peace Conference. The majority of the alterations are changes of wording, mainly of an editorial character, and inserted from a legal standpoint. There are, however, two substantial changes which deserve particular mention.*Article 18 of the original Convention prevented any seizure or detention of an aircraft of one State when passing through the territory of another on the ground that the constitution or mechanism of the aircraft constituted any infringement of a patent, design, or model duly .granted or registered in the State through which the aircraft was passing. Owing to reservations made by two great Powers in respect of this Article, it was necessary to amend it to ensure an agreed text. A compromise was arrived at as shown in Article 18 of the new text, the effect of which is to grant the State interested in the patent the right of detaining the aircraft, provided the aircraft is. immediately released upon the deposit of adequate security.The second alteration of principle Avas the entire deletion of Article 23 of the original text, which defined the legal position of an aircraft and the legal relations of persons on board that aircraft while engaged in an inter-state flight. Objections were made to this Article by other Powers on the ground that the doctrine of territorial sovereignty asserted in Article 1 of the Convention was sufficiently broad to cover all the questions dealt with in Article 23, and therefore that Article 23 was unnecessary.
